subject: statistics
title: Experimental Design: Randomization and Blocking
contentHtml: Experimental design is crucial in machine learning to ensure the accuracy of our models. In this card, we'll explore randomization, blocking, and factorial designs.

problem.statementHtml: A researcher wants to compare the effectiveness of two different fertilizers on plant growth. They have 12 plots of land and want to randomly assign 6 plots to each fertilizer. How can they ensure a fair comparison?
hints: Think about what could go wrong if not done correctly
problem.solutionHtml: To avoid bias, the researcher should randomize the assignment of fertilizers to plots. This ensures that any differences between the two groups are due to the fertilizer itself and not some other factor.

workedExample.problemHtml: A farmer wants to compare the yield of three different crop varieties on their land. They have 18 plots, each with a different combination of soil type, sunlight, and irrigation. How can they design an experiment to determine which variety performs best?

steps.description: Divide the plots into blocks based on the factors that might affect yield
steps.explanation: This ensures that each block has a similar environment

steps.description: Randomly assign one of the three crop varieties to each plot within each block
steps.explanation: This prevents any bias in the assignment

steps.description: Measure and compare the yield of each variety across all blocks
steps.explanation: This allows us to see which variety performs best

workedExample.finalAnswer: The farmer can use a factorial design to compare the three crop varieties while controlling for other factors that might affect yield.

intuition: Randomization and blocking are essential in experimental design to ensure that any differences between groups are due to the treatment itself, not some other factor.
